quiz.title: Algebra 2: Unit 10 Quiz 5
quiz.subtitle: 10.5: Experimental Design
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Principles of controlled experiments, randomization, and control groups

questions.question: A researcher wants to see if a new energy drink improves test scores. She gives one group the drink and another group a flavored water that looks identical. What is the flavored water called?
questions.explanation: A placebo is a fake treatment used as a control to ensure that the results are due to the actual treatment rather than the participants' expectations.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most important factor in ensuring that an experiment can show a cause-and-effect relationship?
options: Random assignment of participants to groups
Having a very large sample size
Conducting the study over many years
questions.explanation: Random assignment helps eliminate confounding variables by ensuring that the experimental and control groups are as similar as possible before the treatment is applied.

questions.question: A study followed 500 people for ten years and found that those who ate more vegetables had lower blood pressure. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: In an observational study, researchers observe individuals and measure variables of interest without attempting to influence the responses. No treatment was assigned here.

questions.question: In a 'double-blind' experiment, who is kept unaware of which participants are receiving the actual treatment?
options: Both the participants and the researchers interacting with them
questions.explanation: Double-blinding prevents bias by ensuring neither the subjects nor the people measuring the results know who belongs to the control or experimental group.

questions.question: A gardener wants to test a new fertilizer that costs \$50 per bag. He applies it to the plants on the sunny side of his house and uses no fertilizer on the plants in the shade. Why is this a poor experimental design?
options: He didn't use a random number generator
questions.explanation: Because the groups differ in both fertilizer use and sunlight, the gardener cannot know which factor caused the growth differences. Sunlight 'confounds' the results.

questions.question: A medical trial for a drug worth \$1,200 per dose uses a control group. What is the primary purpose of the control group?
options: To provide a baseline for comparison
To ensure everyone gets some form of medicine
To reduce the cost of the experiment
To increase the number of participants
questions.explanation: A control group allows researchers to see what would happen to the response variable without the treatment, helping to isolate the treatment's effect.

questions.question: A researcher separates participants into 'Smokers' and 'Non-smokers' before randomly assigning them to two different exercise programs. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: Blocking involves grouping participants by a known characteristic (like smoking status) that might affect the outcome, then randomizing within those blocks.

questions.question: Which of the following describes 'replication' in an experimental context?
options: Using enough experimental units to distinguish a difference from chance
Doing the exact same experiment twice
Assigning participants to groups multiple times
questions.explanation: Replication means using a large enough sample size so that the effects of the treatment can be measured reliably over many subjects.

questions.question: A company tests a new software update on 50 randomly selected computers while leaving 50 others with the old software. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: Because the company actively imposed a treatment (the update) on one group and compared it to a control, it is an experiment.

questions.question: Why is randomization used in the selection of treatment groups?
options: To reduce bias and balance lurking variables
To make the experiment take less time
To ensure the results are exactly what the researcher expects
To make the data easier to calculate
questions.explanation: Randomization helps ensure that the groups are roughly equivalent in all variables except the one being tested.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand the rigor required for scientific proof.
scoreMessages.70: Good work. Remember: only an experiment can prove causation!
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on the difference between observational studies and experiments.
scoreMessages.0: Experimental design is about control. Review placebos and randomization.
